doc.title: Saudi Arabia Banks
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Saudi Arabia Banks Strong loan growth continues but tight liquidity and deposit mix deterioration limits profitabilitySa_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: The Saudi Central Bank published the Monthly Statistical Bulletin for July 2025. Key takeaways:

We believe July data represents a continuation of the positive trends in lending observed in the Saudi banking sector ytd. However, Saudi banks' cost of time deposits may have marginally increased, as can be inferred from the SAIBOR bid data which showed an increase, contributing to a decline in profitability, in our view, with monthly profit before zakat and taxes reaching SR8.2bn in July (down \(16\%\) mom, but up \(7\%\) yoy). Demand deposits decreased during the month, while time deposits increased by \(3\%\) mom, leading to a sequential deterioration in the demand deposit ratio by 1.5pp to \(50\%\) . This is while the headline LDR increased c.1.5pp mom to \(112\%\) , reflecting the low funding headroom and tight liquidity across the sector. Corporate loans were the main driver of loan growth at \(14\%\) ytd while retail loan growth came in at \(3\%\) ytd. We think corporate loan growth remains on track to register low- to mid- teens growth in 2025, and our analysis of project pipelines suggests the corporate loan CAGR could remain at low double digits until the end of the decade, even under a lower oil price scenario. We also anticipate retail lending picking up momentum on further rate cuts.

Amidst the volatile macro and oil price backdrop, while we continue to assume a low- double- digit corporate loan CAGR in our base case, we think downside risk could impact Saudi corporate banks more, especially during a prolonged oil price downturn. As such, we have a preference for banks with a larger retail loan tilt, although we acknowledge these could face some near- term margin pressure. In this context, we think Rajhi and SNB exhibit the greatest resilience: i) they have lower exposure to the corporate loan growth theme given a lower corporate loan tilt, along with a reduction in loan exposure to riskier sectors, and ii) they stand to benefit the most from retail loan growth accelerating on potential rate cuts improving affordability, and mortgage growth picking up on new regulations. Amongst corporate banks, we continue to like, SAB, Riyad and ANB, though these are mainly driven by valuation given deep discounts to history.
Al- Rajhi Bank: Supportive loan mix, positive NIM sensitivity to lower rates, sizable share of NIR to revenue, strong CASA ratio and stage 3 coverage
Saudi National Bank: Strong deposit franchise, one of the highest NII growth rates, elevated Stage 3 coverage, and cheap valuation
Saudi Awwal Bank: Highest capital return, fastest credit growth, robust NII growth, strong fee generation, and attractive valuation
Riyad Bank: Strong deposit franchise, double- digit volume expansion, solid NII growth, and favourable valuation
Arab National Bank: Liquidity, capital return, CASA deposits, and Stage 3 coverage

Loan growth came in at \(0.9\%\) mom in July- 25 following a \(0.6\%\) mom increase in June- 25. Retail loan growth came in at \(0.6\%\) in July- 25 vs. a \(1.1\%\) mom decline in June- 25. Corporate loan growth was \(1.2\%\) mom in July- 25 following a \(2\%\) mom increase in June- 25. Mortgages were up \(11\%\) yoy in 2Q25 and \(1.8\%\) higher qoq (vs. \(2.6\%\) in 1Q25). New residential mortgage finance provided by banks in July- 25 came in at SR6.4bn, up \(21\%\) on a mom basis vs. SR5.3bn in June- 25 but down \(9\%\) yoy.

Deposits decreased by \(0.3\%\) mom following a \(1.1\%\) mom increase in June- 25. The headline loan- to- deposit ratio increased c.1.5pp mom to \(112\%\) in July- 25. The regulatory loan- to- deposit ratio increased from \(81.6\%\) in June- 25 to \(81.9\%\) in July- 25. Meanwhile, the demand deposits ratio decreased from \(52\%\) (June- 25) to \(c.50\%\) as of the end of July- 25, on the back of a \(3\%\) mom decrease in demand deposits, while time, savings and other deposits increased \(3\%\) mom. The decrease in demand deposits was driven by both public sector and businesses and individuals.
Banking sector profitability: Profit before zakat and tax for July- 25 came in at SR8.2bn, which is \(7\%\) higher yoy but \(16\%\) lower mom.
Exhibit 1: SAIBOR bids came in higher qoq (with 3Q25td SAIBOR 3M at 5.42%)
Source: Bloomberg, Datastream
Exhibit 2: Saudi banks' cost of time deposits are highly correlated to their SAIBOR bids
Cost of time deposits for SNB is for its domestic operations
Source: Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 3: Loans were up \(15\%\) yoy, while deposits were up \(8\%\) yoy in Jul-25
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 4: Loans/Deposits were up \(0.9\% /\) down \(0.3\%\) mom in July (vs. up \(0.6\% /\) up \(1.1\%\) mom respectively in June'25)
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 5: Loan-to-deposit ratio increased c.1.5pp mom at \(112\%\) in July-25
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 6: Demand deposits ratio decreased by 1.5pp mom to c.50%
Source:Saudi Central Bank

Exhibit 7: Corporate growth/retail loan growth came in at \(+1.2\% / + 0.6\%\) mom in July-25 (vs. \(+2\% / - 1.1\%\) respectively in June-25) Based on bank credit classified by economic activity split in SAMA monthly data. Retail based on personal loans while corporate makes up the rest.
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 8: Total deposit growth yoy in July-25 was driven by growth in deposits by both private sector and govt entities...
Note: Excluding LOCs, repo transactions and other outstanding balances
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 10: c.68% of the deposits are attributed to the private sector...
Note: Excluding LOCs, repo transactions and other outstanding balances
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 12: Interbank liabilities came in at SR131bn for July'25, with interbank liabilities and repos constituting \(3.7\%\) of total funding...
Note: Saudi Central Bank reports net figure for due to banks & repo at the aggregate level; individual banks could have higher %
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 9: ...with \(3\%\) yoy growth in demand deposits
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 11: ...with the proportion of demand deposits at \(50\%\)
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 13: ...up \(43\%\) yoy
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 14: On a yoy basis, mortgage growth came at \(11\%\) as of the end of 2025 (vs. \(12\%\) in 1025)
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 15: ...and on a qoq basis at \(1.8\%\) in 2025 (vs. \(1.6\%\) in 1025)
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 16: Monthly mortgage origination was up on a sequential basis to SR6.4bn in July-25 from SR5.3bn in June-25 (but down \(9\%\) yoy)
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 17: 2025 quarterly origination came in at c.SR19bn vs. SR27.8bn in 1025
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 18: ...down \(32\%\) qoq...
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 19: ...but up \(4\%\) yoy
Source:Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 20: Rajhi and SNB have the highest market shares in Saudi \\*SNB data prior to 2021 is pro-forma
Source:Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 21: Sector profit before zakat and tax came in at SR8.2bn in July-25 (vs SR9.9bn in June-25)
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 22: ...up 7% yoy...
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 23: ...but down 16% mom
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 24: Reserves were down \(3\%\) mom to US\$444bn in July-25..
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 25: ...and down \(2\%\) yoy
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 26: Bank holdings of government bonds were down \(1\%\) mom to US\$168bn in July-25
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 27: Total value of POS transactions (3m avg) grew \(6\%\) yoy..
Source: Saudi Central Bank
Exhibit 28: ...while average POS transaction value was up \(2\%\) mom to SR60 in July-25
Source: Saudi Central Bank

We, Kazim Andac, Ashwath P T, CFA, Ankita Sarna and Mikhail Butkov, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.
Al- Rajh Bank (Buy, SR94.20), Arab National Bank (Buy, SR23.50), Riyad Bank (Buy, SR25.96), Saudi Awwal Bank (Buy, SR30.16) and Saudi National Bank (Buy, SR34.82)
(as of the market close of August 28, 2025)

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.
Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or

anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.
